## Reviewer's Guide Adds a Flask-based web UI on top of the existing whoistel CLI logic, introduces a persistent history/reporting SQLite database, refactors core phone lookup logic for reuse between CLI and web, and updates tests, docs, dependencies, and internal agent tooling to support the new architecture and review workflow. #### Sequence diagram for web UI number lookup and spam reporting ```mermaid sequenceDiagram actor User participant Browser participant FlaskApp as Flask_app participant Whoistel as whoistel_module participant MainDB as whoistel.sqlite3 participant HistoryDB as history.sqlite3 User->>Browser: Enter phone number Browser->>FlaskApp: POST /check (number) FlaskApp->>Whoistel: clean_phone_number(raw_tel) Whoistel-->>FlaskApp: cleaned_number alt invalid_number FlaskApp-->>Browser: Redirect / (flash error) Browser-->>User: Show error else valid_number FlaskApp-->>Browser: Redirect /view/cleaned_number Browser->>FlaskApp: GET /view/ FlaskApp->>Whoistel: clean_phone_number(number) Whoistel-->>FlaskApp: cleaned_number FlaskApp->>Whoistel: setup_db_connection() Whoistel->>MainDB: connect MainDB-->>Whoistel: connection FlaskApp->>Whoistel: get_full_info(conn, cleaned_number) Whoistel->>MainDB: search_number MainDB-->>Whoistel: match rows Whoistel->>MainDB: get_operator_info, get_commune_info MainDB-->>Whoistel: operator/location rows Whoistel-->>FlaskApp: result dict FlaskApp->>HistoryDB: get_spam_count(cleaned_number) HistoryDB-->>FlaskApp: spam_count FlaskApp-->>Browser: Render result.html(result, spam_count) Browser-->>User: Show ARCEP info and spam stats end User->>Browser: Submit report form Browser->>FlaskApp: POST /report (number, date, is_spam, comment) FlaskApp->>Whoistel: clean_phone_number(number) Whoistel-->>FlaskApp: cleaned_number alt valid_report FlaskApp->>HistoryDB: add_report(number, date, is_spam, comment) HistoryDB-->>FlaskApp: commit OK FlaskApp-->>Browser: Redirect /view/number (flash success) else invalid_report FlaskApp-->>Browser: Redirect /view/number (flash error) end ``` #### Entity relationship diagram for the new history SQLite database ```mermaid erDiagram reports { integer id PK text phone_number date report_date integer is_spam text comment timestamp created_at } %% Composite index (phone_number, is_spam) is conceptual, not another entity ``` #### Class diagram for refactored lookup logic and web/history modules ```mermaid classDiagram class whoistel { <> DB_FILE : str REGION_MAP : dict setup_db_connection() : DatabaseError clean_phone_number(raw_tel) get_operator_info(conn, code_operateur) get_commune_info(conn, code_insee) search_number(conn, tel) get_full_info(conn, tel) print_result(result) main() } class DatabaseError { <> } class history_manager { <> DB_FILE : str with_db_connection(func) get_db_connection() init_history_db() add_report(phone_number, report_date, is_spam, comment, conn) get_spam_count(phone_number, conn) get_recent_reports(limit, conn) } class webapp { <> app : Flask MAX_COMMENT_LENGTH : int format_datetime(value, format) get_history_db() get_main_db() close_dbs(error) index() check() view_number(number) handle_db_error(e) report() history() } whoistel <|-- DatabaseError webapp --> whoistel : uses webapp --> history_manager : uses history_manager --> reports : manages class reports { <> id : integer phone_number : text report_date : date is_spam : integer comment : text created_at : timestamp } ``` ### File-Level Changes | Change | Details | Files | | ------ | ------- | ----- | | Refactor whoistel core logic to be reusable, safer, and web-friendly. |
  • Introduce DatabaseError exception and switch setup_db_connection to raise instead of exiting, while enabling sqlite3.Row row_factory for dict-style access.
  • Add clean_phone_number helper and tighten number validation; ensure CLI errors go to stderr and warn on non-10-digit numbers while still attempting lookup.
  • Split lookup pipeline into get_full_info (building a structured result dict) and print_result (pure presentation using that dict) so web and CLI share the same core behavior.
  • Switch SQL access in get_operator_info/get_commune_info/search_number to use named columns, and add REGION_MAP plus region fallback when commune details are missing.
  • Validate operator email and URL fields (using email-validator and urllib.parse) to avoid outputting malformed or potentially unsafe links.
| `whoistel.py` | | Replace DB test bootstrap with an in-process temporary ARCEP-like SQLite database for tests. |
  • Remove test-level fixture that shells out to updatearcep.sh and instead create a temporary SQLite DB with minimal schema and seed data for PlagesNumerosGeographiques, PlagesNumeros, Operateurs, and Communes.
  • Patch whoistel.DB_FILE during the test session to point to the temporary DB and clean it up afterwards.
| `tests/test_whoistel.py`
`tests/conftest.py` | | Add a Flask web application exposing search, result display, spam reporting, and history views backed by a new history SQLite database. |
  • Create webapp.py with Flask routes for index (/), number checking (/check), result display (/view/), spam/report submission (/report), and history listing (/history).
  • Use SECRET_KEY from environment and Flask-WTF CSRF protection on forms; add a Jinja2 datetime formatting filter and per-request DB connection management via flask.g.
  • Reuse whoistel.clean_phone_number and whoistel.get_full_info for main ARCEP lookups, and surface DatabaseError as a user-friendly error page.
| `webapp.py` | | Introduce a dedicated history manager layer backed by a separate SQLite database. |
  • Create history_manager.get_db_connection with sqlite3.Row row_factory and DB_FILE configurable via HISTORY_DB_FILE env var.
  • Add init_history_db to create reports table and indexes idempotently at app startup.
  • Provide add_report, get_spam_count, and get_recent_reports functions, with an internal with_db_connection decorator that opens/closes a connection when one is not supplied.
| `history_manager.py` | | Add web UI templates, static styling, and error views for the Flask app. |
  • Create base layout.html with navigation, flash message rendering, and CSS inclusion.
  • Implement index.html search form with CSRF token, result.html showing ARCEP data, operator and location info, plus community spam stats and report form, history.html listing recent reports, and error.html for generic error display.
  • Add a simple static/style.css for layout, tables, flash messages, and status styling for different result types.
| `templates/layout.html`
`templates/index.html`
`templates/result.html`
`templates/history.html`
`templates/error.html`
`static/style.css` | | Expand automated tests to cover web behavior, new helpers, and validation logic. |
  • Add tests for clean_phone_number and operator email/URL validation, including mocking sqlite rows to exercise invalid cases.
  • Add tests for the Flask app covering index rendering, check redirect, number view behavior (including unknown numbers and cleaning/redirect), reporting flow and history display, DB error handling, comment truncation, and CSRF behavior.
  • Update existing invalid-number test to assert on the new error message wording that mentions cleaning ("apr√®s nettoyage").
| `tests/test_whoistel.py`
`tests/test_webapp.py` | | Document and support the web app, container, and updated agent workflow. |
  • Extend README with instructions for running the web app locally and in production via gunicorn, including justification for single-worker usage with SQLite.
  • Update TODO to mark web UI and history/reporting tasks as completed and add a future containerization task.
  • Refine AGENTS.md guidance around data sources, data file usage, container expectations, and add a detailed section describing a robust GitHub PR Review Cycle and lessons learned about comment fetching and monitoring.
  • Add helper scripts under agent-tools to analyze, monitor, and verify GitHub PR review comments and state.
| `README.md`
`TODO.md`
`AGENTS.md`
`agent-tools/verify_comments.py`
`agent-tools/monitor_c26.py`
`agent-tools/analyze_c26.py` | | Update project dependencies, container base image, and ignore rules for the new web stack and tools. |
  • Add Flask, Flask-WTF, email-validator, and gunicorn to requirements.txt to support the web application and validation features.
  • Bump Containerfile base image from python:3.11-slim to python:3.14-slim for a newer runtime.
  • Update .gitignore (content not shown in diff) to exclude new generated or tooling-related files as per review tooling changes.

Tips and commands #### Interacting with Sourcery - **Trigger a new review:** Comment `@sourcery-ai review` on the pull request. - **Continue discussions:** Reply directly to Sourcery's review comments. - **Generate a GitHub issue from a review comment:** Ask Sourcery to create an issue from a review comment by replying to it. You can also reply to a review comment with `@sourcery-ai issue` to create an issue from it. - **Generate a pull request title:** Write `@sourcery-ai` anywhere in the pull request title to generate a title at any time. You can also comment `@sourcery-ai title` on the pull request to (re-)generate the title at any time. - **Generate a pull request summary:** Write `@sourcery-ai summary` anywhere in the pull request body to generate a PR summary at any time exactly where you want it. You can also comment `@sourcery-ai summary` on the pull request to (re-)generate the summary at any time. - **Generate reviewer's guide:** Comment `@sourcery-ai guide` on the pull request to (re-)generate the reviewer's guide at any time. - **Resolve all Sourcery comments:** Comment `@sourcery-ai resolve` on the pull request to resolve all Sourcery comments. Useful if you've already addressed all the comments and don't want to see them anymore. - **Dismiss all Sourcery reviews:** Comment `@sourcery-ai dismiss` on the pull request to dismiss all existing Sourcery reviews. Especially useful if you want to start fresh with a new review - don't forget to comment `@sourcery-ai review` to trigger a new review! #### Customizing Your Experience Access your [dashboard](https://app.sourcery.ai) to: - Enable or disable review features such as the Sourcery-generated pull request summary, the reviewer's guide, and others. - Change the review language. - Add, remove or edit custom review instructions. - Adjust other review settings. #### Getting Help - [Contact our support team](mailto:support@sourcery.ai) for questions or feedback. - Visit our [documentation](https://docs.sourcery.ai) for detailed guides and information. - Keep in touch with the Sourcery team by following us on [X/Twitter](https://x.com/SourceryAI), [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/company/sourcery-ai/) or [GitHub](https://github.com/sourcery-ai).

üìù Walkthrough ## Walkthrough Adds a Flask web UI and templates for phone-number lookup/reporting, a SQLite-backed history module, refactors CLI for input normalization and exception-based DB errors, introduces tests and agent-tools utilities, updates dependencies and Containerfile base image, and expands .gitignore and docs. ## Changes | Cohort / File(s) | Summary | |---|---| | **Web Application & Routing**
`webapp.py` | New Flask app with routes for index, check, view, report, history; CSRF, per-request DB helpers, format_datetime filter, input validation, DatabaseError handler, MAX_COMMENT_LENGTH. | | **History & Reporting Backend**
`history_manager.py`, `history.sqlite3` | New history module and DB schema: configurable DB_FILE, get_db_connection, init_history_db, with_db_connection decorator, add_report, get_spam_count, get_recent_reports. | | **Core CLI Refactor**
`whoistel.py` | Refactor: clean_phone_number, DatabaseError, REGION_MAP, get_full_info, print_result, sqlite3.Row usage, structured result objects and exception-based DB errors. | | **Templates (Jinja2)**
`templates/...`
`templates/layout.html`, `templates/index.html`, `templates/result.html`, `templates/history.html`, `templates/error.html` | New French-localized templates: base layout, search form, result with report form, history view, and error page. | | **Frontend Styling**
`static/style.css` | New CSS for layout, forms, buttons, result boxes (error/success/community), tables, textarea, and helpers. | | **Tests**
`tests/...`
`tests/conftest.py`, `tests/test_webapp.py`, `tests/test_whoistel.py` | New fixtures and tests: temp DB setup, webapp endpoint tests (CSRF, reporting, redirects, DB error), updated CLI tests (cleaning, operator info validation). | | **Agent Tools**
`agent-tools/...`
`agent-tools/analyze_c26.py`, `agent-tools/monitor_c26.py`, `agent-tools/verify_comments.py` | New utilities for comment analysis, PR-review monitoring (GitHub CLI polling), and comment/file verification heuristics. | | **Dependencies**
`requirements.txt` | Adds `Flask`, `Flask-WTF`, `email-validator`, `gunicorn` (pandas retained). | | **Container & Packaging**
`Containerfile`, `whoistel.container` | Base image bumped to `python:3.14-slim`, adds system deps, copies app files, exposes port 5000, uses Gunicorn ENTRYPOINT/CMD, and adds a systemd unit for container. | | **Ignore Rules**
`.gitignore` | Expanded ignore patterns: Python artifacts, DB files, logs, many development/artifact-specific entries and directories. | | **Documentation & Metadata**
`README.md`, `AGENTS.md`, `TODO.md` | README adds Web Application section and deployment notes; AGENTS.md adds PR review guidance; TODO.md records sprint items and many completed tasks. | ## Sequence Diagram(s) ```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant User as User / Browser participant Flask as Flask (webapp.py) participant MainDB as Main DB (whoistel) participant HistDB as History DB (history_manager) rect rgb(210,230,255) User->>Flask: GET / Flask-->>User: index.html User->>Flask: POST /check (number) Flask->>Flask: clean_phone_number(), validate Flask-->>User: Redirect /view/ User->>Flask: GET /view/ Flask->>MainDB: get_full_info(conn, tel) MainDB-->>Flask: result (operator, location) Flask->>HistDB: get_spam_count(number) HistDB-->>Flask: spam count Flask-->>User: result.html end rect rgb(255,230,230) User->>Flask: POST /report (number, date, spam, comment) Flask->>Flask: validate, truncate comment Flask->>HistDB: add_report(...) HistDB-->>Flask: success Flask-->>User: flash + redirect end rect rgb(230,255,230) User->>Flask: GET /history Flask->>HistDB: get_recent_reports(limit) HistDB-->>Flask: reports list Flask-->>User: history.html end ``` ## Estimated code review effort üéØ 4 (Complex) | ‚è±Ô∏è ~60 minutes ## Poem > üê∞ I nibble keys beneath the moonlit log, > I tidy numbers, stitch a tiny web of bog, > SQLite burrows keep each report snug, > Templates bloom, CSS gives a cozy hug, > Hop‚Äîdeploy the patch, then munch a carrot cog.

Hey there - I've reviewed your changes - here's some feedback: - In `whoistel.main()`, the `if not cleaned_number.isdigit():` block appears to have inconsistent indentation in the diff (the `print`/`sys.exit` lines are more indented than the `if`), which would raise an `IndentationError` at runtime; double-check and normalize this block‚Äôs indentation. - The new web UI and history system introduce additional SQLite files (`whoistel.sqlite3` and `history.sqlite3`); you might want to centralize their paths/configuration (e.g., via environment variables or a single config module) so deployment and testing environments can override locations without touching code.
Prompt for AI Agents ~~~markdown Please address the comments from this code review: ## Overall Comments - In `whoistel.main()`, the `if not cleaned_number.isdigit():` block appears to have inconsistent indentation in the diff (the `print`/`sys.exit` lines are more indented than the `if`), which would raise an `IndentationError` at runtime; double-check and normalize this block‚Äôs indentation. - The new web UI and history system introduce additional SQLite files (`whoistel.sqlite3` and `history.sqlite3`); you might want to centralize their paths/configuration (e.g., via environment variables or a single config module) so deployment and testing environments can override locations without touching code. ## Individual Comments ### Comment 1 `Containerfile:2` # Use an official Python runtime as a parent image -FROM python:3.11-slim +FROM python:3.14-slim # Set environment variables to prevent Python from writing .pyc files and to run in unbuffered mode **issue (bug_risk):** Using `python:3.14-slim` is risky since that tag may not exist or be supported yet. This may cause builds to fail if the 3.14 image isn‚Äôt available yet or dependencies don‚Äôt support it. Prefer pinning to a currently released version (e.g. 3.12/3.13) or making the Python version configurable so you can control when to adopt new releases. ### Comment 2 `tests/test_whoistel.py:73-80` + assert result.returncode == 1 + assert "uniquement des chiffres apr√®s nettoyage" in result.stderr + +def test_clean_phone_number(): + """Tests the phone number cleaning logic.""" + from whoistel import clean_phone_number + assert clean_phone_number("01.02.03.04.05") == "0102030405" + assert clean_phone_number("+33 1 02 03 04 05") == "0102030405" + assert clean_phone_number("+33 (0) 6 12 34 56 78") == "0612345678" + assert clean_phone_number("06-12-34-56-78") == "0612345678" + assert clean_phone_number("06\t12 34\n56 78") == "0612345678" + +def test_operator_info_validation(): **suggestion (testing):** Consider adding tests for empty/None input to `clean_phone_number` `clean_phone_number` returns an empty string for falsy input, but `test_clean_phone_number` only covers formatted valid numbers. Please add tests for cases like `clean_phone_number("") == ""` and `clean_phone_number(None) == ""` to lock in this behavior and guard against regressions when inputs are missing. ```suggestion def test_clean_phone_number(): """Tests the phone number cleaning logic.""" from whoistel import clean_phone_number # Formatted valid numbers assert clean_phone_number("01.02.03.04.05") == "0102030405" assert clean_phone_number("+33 1 02 03 04 05") == "0102030405" assert clean_phone_number("+33 (0) 6 12 34 56 78") == "0612345678" assert clean_phone_number("06-12-34-56-78") == "0612345678" assert clean_phone_number("06\t12 34\n56 78") == "0612345678" # Falsy / missing inputs assert clean_phone_number("") == "" assert clean_phone_number(None) == "" ``` ### Comment 3 `tests/test_webapp.py:38-41` + rv = client.get('/') + assert b'Rechercher un num' in rv.data + +def test_check_number_redirect(client): + rv = client.post('/check', data={'number': '0123456789'}) + assert rv.status_code == 302 + assert '/view/0123456789' in rv.location + +def test_view_number_unknown(client): **suggestion (testing):** Add tests for `/check` and `/report` validation error paths (missing/invalid number, empty report) The current web tests only cover the happy-path redirect and main `/report` flow; the validation branches are untested. Please add tests that: - Post to `/check` with an empty `number` and assert the expected flash message ("Veuillez saisir un num√©ro.") and redirect to `/`. - Post to `/check` with an invalid value (e.g. `"abcd"`) and assert the invalid-characters flash and redirect behavior. - Post to `/report` with `number` set but `is_spam` unchecked, and both `comment` and `date` empty, and assert the error flash about needing at least one of those fields and the redirect back to `view_number`. This will ensure the new UI‚Äôs validation and error handling are properly covered by tests. Suggested implementation: ```python def test_check_number_redirect(client): rv = client.post('/check', data={'number': '0123456789'}) assert rv.status_code == 302 assert '/view/0123456789' in rv.location def test_check_number_missing_number_validation_error(client): rv = client.post('/check', data={'number': ''}, follow_redirects=True) # Should flash that a number is required and redirect back to the index assert b'Veuillez saisir un num' in rv.data assert b'Rechercher un num' in rv.data def test_check_number_invalid_number_validation_error(client): rv = client.post('/check', data={'number': 'abcd'}, follow_redirects=True) # Should flash an invalid-characters error and redirect back to the index assert b'caract\xc3\xa8res invalides' in rv.data or b'num\xc3\xa9ro invalide' in rv.data assert b'Rechercher un num' in rv.data def test_view_number_unknown(client): ``` ```python def test_report_validation_error_requires_at_least_one_field(client): rv = client.post('/report', data={ 'number': '0123456789', # Explicitly leave all optional fields empty / unchecked 'is_spam': '', 'comment': '', 'date': '', }, follow_redirects=True) # Should redirect back to the view page for that number assert b'0123456789' in rv.data # Should flash an error about needing at least spam/comment/date assert ( b'cocher spam' in rv.data or b"au moins l'un des champs" in rv.data or b'commentaire, une date ou le statut spam' in rv.data ) def test_report_flow(client): # 1. Report a number as spam rv = client.post('/report', data={ 'number': '0987654321', ``` The exact flash message strings for: - invalid `/check` number, and - the `/report` "at least one of spam/comment/date" error may differ in your application. You should update the `assert` conditions in `test_check_number_invalid_number_validation_error` and `test_report_validation_error_requires_at_least_one_field` to match the actual French messages used in your views or templates (ideally asserting on the full, precise byte string rather than the current set of `or` clauses). ### Comment 4 `tests/test_webapp.py:43-48` + assert rv.status_code == 302 + assert '/view/0123456789' in rv.location + +def test_view_number_unknown(client): + # Tests checking a number that likely doesn't exist or is generic + rv = client.get('/view/0123456789') + assert b'0123456789' in rv.data + # Check if spam count is 0 + assert b'signal\xc3\xa9 comme spam 0 fois' in rv.data + +def test_report_flow(client): **suggestion (testing):** Consider testing `/view` error handling for invalid number formats and `DatabaseError` in combination You already cover the `DatabaseError` handler and the normal `/view/` path, but coverage is missing for key branches: - A non-numeric cleaned value (e.g. `/view/abcd`) should return 400 and render `error.html`; a test for this would lock in that behavior. - You currently trigger `DatabaseError` only for a valid number. Adding a test where a DB error occurs after a "dirty" number is normalized/redirected would verify that redirect + error handling interact correctly. These additions would better exercise the routing and error paths around `/view`. Suggested implementation: ```python def test_report_flow(client): # 1. Report a number as spam rv = client.post('/report', data={ 'number': '0987654321', 'date': '2023-01-01', 'is_spam': 'on', 'comment': 'Test Spam' }, follow_redirects=True) assert rv.status_code == 200 # Should see the updated count in the result page (since it redirects to view) def test_view_invalid_number_format_returns_400(client): # A completely non-numeric number should be rejected and return 400 rv = client.get('/view/abcd') assert rv.status_code == 400 def test_view_dirty_number_database_error_after_normalization(client, monkeypatch): """ Ensure that when a 'dirty' number is normalized/redirected and then a DatabaseError occurs while loading its details, the error handler is still invoked correctly. """ # Import the view module where the DB-accessing function used by /view resides. # This should match the module/function you already patch in your existing # DatabaseError test for /view/. from webapp import views # adjust to your actual views module # Patch the lower-level function that fetches number details so that, after # the number has been normalized, the DB layer raises DatabaseError. from psycopg2 import DatabaseError # adjust if you use a different DatabaseError class def _raise_db_error(*args, **kwargs): raise DatabaseError("Simulated DB failure after normalization") # Replace 'get_number_details' with the actual function used by your /view route. monkeypatch.setattr(views, "get_number_details", _raise_db_error) # Use a "dirty" formatted number that your app will normalize before hitting the DB. rv = client.get('/view/+33%2001%2023%2045%2067%2089') # We expect the DatabaseError handler to be triggered; usually this is a 500 or # whatever status code you return in your error handler. assert rv.status_code >= 500 ``` The `test_view_dirty_number_database_error_after_normalization` test assumes: 1. Your views module is importable as `webapp.views`. 2. The function doing the DB access from `/view/` is named `get_number_details`. 3. You use `psycopg2.DatabaseError` as the raised exception. 4. A ‚Äúdirty‚Äù number like `+33 01 23 45 67 89` is normalized by the `/view` handler. To fully integrate this into your codebase, you should: 1. Update the `from webapp import views` import to point at the actual module where the `/view` route (and the DB-accessing function it calls) is defined. 2. Adjust `"get_number_details"` in `monkeypatch.setattr` to the exact function your `/view` route uses to hit the database (mirror whatever you patch in your existing DatabaseError test). 3.
